file_content.text: We have updated command on the situation.
The plans are on their way to command. When reinforcements arrive, these bugs are done for.
Well, look at that. Victorious combatants returning, and I do believe every one is from a two-legged species.
I hope you enjoyed yourselves getting the plans to that detonator.
Please observe, gentlemen, a determined individual returning to us in victory.
I hope you enjoyed yourself getting the plans to that detonator.
Here's what you want.
I got it done.
Bugs die like anything else.
Spectacular. Take a look at those schematics, Ganbar. That's what the resistance wants on your doorstep.
I can still smell burned carapaces. Nothing else in the galaxy smells like that.
Crushing them was satisfying.
Glad to have given you the opportunity.
Now, would you care to reveal to these beleaguered military specimens the secret of your success?
Superior training, superior instinct, superior... I'll stop there.
Sure, I can brag.
You hear that? Humor is a sign of spirit. Unlike some, our friend here put that spirit into action.
And what one Imperial can do, another Imperial can do. It's all motivation.
Sir, if we just have to eliminate stragglers, I believe we are capable of another assault.
You will make one. But the objective is met, the lesson learned. Don't worry, Ganbar. You'll all see action again soon.
Private Suzoku said your tactics were what made the difference. Specifically, they failed.
You sent your men in to die.
I gave the orders I had to. The bugs jumped us, and we had to let them know we weren't prey.
We would have succeeded if we'd given it our all. It was a question of motivation.
You got beat three times by technologically inferior opponents.
More like stupidity.
We just needed--nevermind, I can see how the facts look. It won't happen again.
You wasted Imperial lives on a personally derived mission. Your career is done.
You acted on your own.
Tribunals exist for failures like yours.
Tell it to a review council.
My squad will stand behind me. We've weathered worse together. Right, Ganbar? Erelut?
I see. Then it's time to contact the base camp. Before I end up in a court, I have some bomb plans to turn over.
Leave. Now.
Yes... yes, my lord.
Leave. Now.
Right. No reason to stay in a combat zone longer than needed.
All right, gents. Contact base camp in Sobrik. We have what we came for.
You're looking for any and all documents related to the construction of a neutron detonator.
Sir, we just took fifty percent casualties. That's called a defeat. We're dead without reinforcements.
Where are you, Private? Does this look like Alderaan? On Balmorra, fifty percent is the price of admission.
Everyone fights, Private Ganbar. Either you go in shooting or we freeze you in carbonite and use you as a shield.
That casualty rate seems high.
What killed so many men?
Well, I imagine you're new to our particular combat zone, so welcome. I'm Piloc.
Report, Lieutenant.
Another fine day in the combat zone. I'm Piloc, squad lieutenant.
Things are looking up now that your squad is here. I'm Lieutenant Piloc.
I like your attitude, Lieutenant.
Truer words never spoken.
And I like your numbers. We're a little low ourselves. The morning wasn't too kind to us.
A bit of enthusiasm helps on days like today.
We've encountered an unidentified insectoid species.
They're three meters tall! Blasters don't kill them! They can chew through armor!
Private Ganbar here is expressing the diminished morale that resulted from our failure to achieve the objective.
What's so necessary that it costs this many lives?
What's your objective?
There are plans for a bomb in that industrial complex. A city-busting neutron detonator. If the resistance gets them, you can kiss Sobrik goodbye.
Trouble is, some kind of alien bugs took up residence. They've got brains enough to fight, but not enough to talk.
What needs to be done?
Hysteria tells me nothing.
The bugs are dug into that industrial complex--which is very bad for us.
There's plans for a bomb in there, a city-busting neutron detonator. If the resistance gets those, we can kiss Sobrik goodbye.
Shoot the mouthy one and the rest will fall in line.
Make an example of this worm.
Uh, sir? Speaking solely for the team and given that we already shot Private Camm....
A neutron detonator can wipe out a city, Private. If there's plans for one in there, I want all available manpower for this objective.
Oh, thank the Force.
We'll be back in combat as soon as we get done with a little field surgery.
You keep your men alive. I'll get those plans.
Save your energy. I'll do it.
I never turn down Tarisian ale or free firepower. You've got yourself a deal.
How much medical attention does the squad need?
Who's still functional?
We've got concussions, a fractured arm, a hand with no meat on it, and our medics are tied up removing a rib from a lung.
Everyone left in that complex is dead. The insectoids appear to, uh, consume their enemies.
So, as less than half of us can even walk, can you give us a hand? Go in and get those schematics out?
I was in the moment you mentioned plans to a bomb.
Secrets are my business.
I thought that might command some attention. It certainly got mine.
The insects will learn fear, and if they are incapable of that, pain.
They will suffer for this.
My lord, that is a scenario that meets our approval.
I will do this, though not for them. I will do it because I succeed where others fail.
I'll do this--my way.
Understood, my lord.
I can step on a few bugs for a good cause.
If you need the help.
Now that's the kind of soldier I need. One with no fear, and big boots.
Step aside.
Now, I should warn you. The plans are separated out for the manufacture of individual parts, so it's not one straight run in there.
Once you have all the plans, come back and tell us how you did it. I need the squad to hear that these bugs can die.
I think not. [Refuse quest]
Forget it. [Refuse quest]
All right, gents. Looks like you're going to have to work for a living after all.
Nothing to see here. Private discussion.
